title: How to Make Fried Farro

methods.name: Serving Farro with Eggs and Veggies

steps.headline: Cut your veggies.
steps.description: Trim the scallions’ green ends from the white and slice them up separately. Peel and chop your ginger and garlic. Slice your carrot.

steps.headline: Boil your farro.
steps.description: Fill ⅔ of a medium saucepan with water. Turn the burner to medium-high heat. Dump your farro in once the water comes to a boil. Cook for roughly 15 minutes, or until the farro turns chewy and tender. Drain the farro through a strainer.

steps.headline: Make a seasoned scallion-white mix.
steps.description: While the farro boils, transfer your scallion whites to a small mixing bowl. Add your garlic, ginger, crushed red pepper, sugar, and ½ teaspoon of your salt. Stir to combine.

steps.headline: Saute your carrots and scallion-white mix.
steps.description: Coat the bottom of a large skillet with 1 tablespoon of the vegetable oil and then turn the burner to medium high-heat. Saute your carrots for two minutes, or until they start to become tender. Add your scallion-white mix and cook for another 30 seconds.

steps.headline: Add your farro and other veggies.
steps.description: Stir your boiled farro in, plus the peas, beans sprouts, and about half of your scallion greens. Then stir in your soy sauce and sesame oil for flavoring. Fry them all together for two minutes, then scoop it out into a serving dish.

steps.headline: Cook your eggs.
steps.description: Wipe your skillet clean of any lingering food. Then coat the bottom with another teaspoon of vegetable oil. Crack the eggs open and sprinkle the remaining salt over them. Cook them as is until bubbles begin to form. Start stirring them non-stop at this point for about 30 seconds, or until they have fully cooked.

steps.headline: Complete your dish.
steps.description: Transfer the eggs to your serving dish. Stir them into the farro. Garnish with the other half of your scallions and serve. Store any leftovers in an airtight container within two hours of cooking and refrigerate. They should last between three or four days. Freezing them may make them last longer, but will ruin the eggs' texture.

methods.name: Pairing Farro with Shrimp and Poached Eggs

steps.headline: Make your farro.
steps.description: Fill a medium saucepan about ⅔ of the way full with water. Bring it to a boil over medium high-heat. Once it boils, add your farro. Let it boil for about 15 minutes, or until the farro becomes chewy and tender. Then drain the water from the farro with a strainer.

steps.headline: Prep your other ingredients.
steps.description: Peel your shrimp and remove the veins while the farro cooks. Then peel and mince your garlic. Do the same with your ginger. Chop your scallions.

steps.headline: Cook your shrimp.
steps.description: Add the vegetable oil to a large skillet. Turn the burner to medium-high heat. Once the oil heats up, dump your garlic and ginger in and stir them around for a few seconds, until they become fragrant. Then place your shrimp in the skillet and cook them for two to three minutes, flipping occasionally.

steps.headline: Combine with farro and wet ingredients.
steps.description: Place the farro in the skillet with the shrimp and stir them together. Add the soy sauce, sesame oil, and rice vinegar. Stir everything together until hot.

steps.headline: Poach your eggs.
steps.description: Fill your saucepan ⅔ of the way full again with water. Bring to a boil, then lower the heat to simmer. Crack each egg open into a separate measuring cup and lower them into the water, one after the other. Simmer for about four to five minutes, then scoop them out of the water with a slotted spoon.

steps.headline: Arrange your plates and serve.
steps.description: Divide the farro equally between four plates. Switch shrimps from plate to plate if necessary for equal portions. Garnish with scallions. Then top each plate with a poached egg and serve. Store any leftovers in an airtight container within two hours of cooking and refrigerate. They should last between three or four days. Freezing them may make them last longer, but will ruin the eggs' texture.

steps.headline: Cook your farro.
steps.description: Add the dry farro to a medium saucepan and toast it for ten minutes, stirring occasionally. Then pour in the water. Once that comes to a boil, lower the heat and simmer for 15 to 20 minutes, or until the farro turns tender. Remove the skillet from the burner and let sit for about five to ten minutes.

steps.headline: Prep your veggies.
steps.description: While the farro cooks and cools, get your veggies ready. Peel and chop your garlic. Dice your onions and pepper. Slice your mushrooms.

steps.headline: Saute your veggies and farro.
steps.description: First, coat the bottom of a large skillet with ½ tablespoon of your sesame oil. Turn the burner to medium-high heat. Add the onion, garlic, pepper, mushrooms, and spinach and sautee for a few minutes. Then stir in the farro along with your crushed red pepper, soy sauce, and remaining sesame oil. Remove from heat and serve right away. Seal any leftovers in an airtight container. Store in the fridge for up to three to four days in the fridge or two months in the freezer.

text: Serving Farro with Eggs and Veggies Cut your veggies. Trim the scallions’ green ends from the white and slice them up separately. Peel and chop your ginger and garlic. Slice your carrot. Boil your farro. Fill ⅔ of a medium saucepan with water. Turn the burner to medium-high heat. Dump your farro in once the water comes to a boil. Cook for roughly 15 minutes, or until the farro turns chewy and tender. Drain the farro through a strainer. Make a seasoned scallion-white mix. While the farro boils, transfer your scallion whites to a small mixing bowl. Add your garlic, ginger, crushed red pepper, sugar, and ½ teaspoon of your salt. Stir to combine. Saute your carrots and scallion-white mix. Coat the bottom of a large skillet with 1 tablespoon of the vegetable oil and then turn the burner to medium high-heat. Saute your carrots for two minutes, or until they start to become tender. Add your scallion-white mix and cook for another 30 seconds. Add your farro and other veggies. Stir your boiled farro in, plus the peas, beans sprouts, and about half of your scallion greens. Then stir in your soy sauce and sesame oil for flavoring. Fry them all together for two minutes, then scoop it out into a serving dish. Cook your eggs. Wipe your skillet clean of any lingering food. Then coat the bottom with another teaspoon of vegetable oil. Crack the eggs open and sprinkle the remaining salt over them. Cook them as is until bubbles begin to form. Start stirring them non-stop at this point for about 30 seconds, or until they have fully cooked. Complete your dish. Transfer the eggs to your serving dish. Stir them into the farro. Garnish with the other half of your scallions and serve. Store any leftovers in an airtight container within two hours of cooking and refrigerate. They should last between three or four days. Freezing them may make them last longer, but will ruin the eggs' texture. Pairing Farro with Shrimp and Poached Eggs Make your farro. Fill a medium saucepan about ⅔ of the way full with water. Do the same with your ginger. Chop your scallions. Cook your shrimp. Add the vegetable oil to a large skillet. Turn the burner to medium-high heat. Once the oil heats up, dump your garlic and ginger in and stir them around for a few seconds, until they become fragrant. Then place your shrimp in the skillet and cook them for two to three minutes, flipping occasionally. Combine with farro and wet ingredients. Place the farro in the skillet with the shrimp and stir them together. Add the soy sauce, sesame oil, and rice vinegar. Stir everything together until hot. Poach your eggs. Fill your saucepan ⅔ of the way full again with water. Bring to a boil, then lower the heat to simmer. Crack each egg open into a separate measuring cup and lower them into the water, one after the other. Simmer for about four to five minutes, then scoop them out of the water with a slotted spoon. Arrange your plates and serve. Divide the farro equally between four plates. Switch shrimps from plate to plate if necessary for equal portions. Garnish with scallions. Then top each plate with a poached egg and serve. Store any leftovers in an airtight container within two hours of cooking and refrigerate. They should last between three or four days. Freezing them may make them last longer, but will ruin the eggs' texture. Frying Up Some Vegan Farro Cook your farro. Add the dry farro to a medium saucepan and toast it for ten minutes, stirring occasionally. Then pour in the water. Once that comes to a boil, lower the heat and simmer for 15 to 20 minutes, or until the farro turns tender. Remove the skillet from the burner and let sit for about five to ten minutes. Prep your veggies. While the farro cooks and cools, get your veggies ready. Peel and chop your garlic. Dice your onions and pepper. Slice your mushrooms. Saute your veggies and farro. First, coat the bottom of a large skillet with ½ tablespoon of your sesame oil. Turn the burner to medium-high heat. Add the onion, garlic, pepper, mushrooms, and spinach and sautee for a few minutes. Then stir in the farro along with your crushed red pepper, soy sauce, and remaining sesame oil. Remove from heat and serve right away. Seal any leftovers in an airtight container. Store in the fridge for up to three to four days in the fridge or two months in the freezer.

Trim the scallions’ green ends from the white and slice them up separately.
Peel and chop your ginger and garlic.
Slice your carrot.
Boil your farro.
Fill ⅔ of a medium saucepan with water.
Turn the burner to medium-high heat.
Dump your farro in once the water comes to a boil.
Cook for roughly 15 minutes, or until the farro turns chewy and tender.
Drain the farro through a strainer.
Make a seasoned scallion-white mix.
While the farro boils, transfer your scallion whites to a small mixing bowl.
Add your garlic, ginger, crushed red pepper, sugar, and ½ teaspoon of your salt.
Stir to combine.
Saute your carrots and scallion-white mix.
Coat the bottom of a large skillet with 1 tablespoon of the vegetable oil and then turn the burner to medium high-heat.
Saute your carrots for two minutes, or until they start to become tender.
Add your scallion-white mix and cook for another 30 seconds.
Add your farro and other veggies.
Stir your boiled farro in, plus the peas, beans sprouts, and about half of your scallion greens.
Then stir in your soy sauce and sesame oil for flavoring.
Fry them all together for two minutes, then scoop it out into a serving dish.
Cook your eggs.
Wipe your skillet clean of any lingering food.
Then coat the bottom with another teaspoon of vegetable oil.
Crack the eggs open and sprinkle the remaining salt over them.
Cook them as is until bubbles begin to form.
Start stirring them non-stop at this point for about 30 seconds, or until they have fully cooked.
Complete your dish.
Transfer the eggs to your serving dish.
Stir them into the farro.
Garnish with the other half of your scallions and serve.
Store any leftovers in an airtight container within two hours of cooking and refrigerate.
They should last between three or four days.
Freezing them may make them last longer, but will ruin the eggs' texture.
Pairing Farro with Shrimp and Poached Eggs Make your farro.
Fill a medium saucepan about ⅔ of the way full with water.
Bring it to a boil over medium high-heat.
Once it boils, add your farro.
Let it boil for about 15 minutes, or until the farro becomes chewy and tender.
Then drain the water from the farro with a strainer.
Prep your other ingredients.
Peel your shrimp and remove the veins while the farro cooks.
Then peel and mince your garlic.
Do the same with your ginger.
Chop your scallions.
Cook your shrimp.
Add the vegetable oil to a large skillet.
Turn the burner to medium-high heat.
Once the oil heats up, dump your garlic and ginger in and stir them around for a few seconds, until they become fragrant.
Then place your shrimp in the skillet and cook them for two to three minutes, flipping occasionally.
Combine with farro and wet ingredients.
Place the farro in the skillet with the shrimp and stir them together.
Add the soy sauce, sesame oil, and rice vinegar.
Stir everything together until hot.
Poach your eggs.
Fill your saucepan ⅔ of the way full again with water.
Bring to a boil, then lower the heat to simmer.
Crack each egg open into a separate measuring cup and lower them into the water, one after the other.
Simmer for about four to five minutes, then scoop them out of the water with a slotted spoon.
Arrange your plates and serve.
Divide the farro equally between four plates.
Switch shrimps from plate to plate if necessary for equal portions.
Garnish with scallions.
Then top each plate with a poached egg and serve.
Store any leftovers in an airtight container within two hours of cooking and refrigerate.
They should last between three or four days.
Freezing them may make them last longer, but will ruin the eggs' texture.
Frying Up Some Vegan Farro Cook your farro.
Add the dry farro to a medium saucepan and toast it for ten minutes, stirring occasionally.
Then pour in the water.
Once that comes to a boil, lower the heat and simmer for 15 to 20 minutes, or until the farro turns tender.
Remove the skillet from the burner and let sit for about five to ten minutes.
Prep your veggies.
While the farro cooks and cools, get your veggies ready.
Peel and chop your garlic.
Dice your onions and pepper.
Slice your mushrooms.
Saute your veggies and farro.
First, coat the bottom of a large skillet with ½ tablespoon of your sesame oil.
Turn the burner to medium-high heat.
Add the onion, garlic, pepper, mushrooms, and spinach and sautee for a few minutes.
Then stir in the farro along with your crushed red pepper, soy sauce, and remaining sesame oil.
Remove from heat and serve right away.
Seal any leftovers in an airtight container.
Store in the fridge for up to three to four days in the fridge or two months in the freezer.
